It is possible that novelty search or some variant of it can help in disc=
ontinuous problems because it is likely that a mediocre continuous solution=
 that is easier to find can become a deceptive trap for fitness-based searc=
h.  In other words, once a continuous policy is discovered that does okay, =
it might be hard to break away from that mold.  On the other hand, represen=
tation also plays a role in the bias of the encoding towards continuity or =
discontinuity, so that bias will still influence the outcome even with nove=
lty search.  However, it's important to note that representations that are =
explicitly designed to easily represent discontinuity are likely to be sacr=
ificing the ability to represent and elaborate on regularities.  That is, t=
here may be a subtle trade-off, so it is important to be careful about givi=
ng too much weight to the need to capture discontinuity.  We can see in Pic=
breeder that CPPNs can produce patterns with clear regional differentiation=
, so the issue is certainly further complicated by the means by which evolu=
tion was performed.

It is also likely that in the real world highly fractu=
red problems are not solved entirely through genetics.  That is, synaptic p=
lasticity probably plays a big role, complicating the issue further.  For e=
xample, it is possible that the pattern of plasticity rules itself is not f=
ractured but that the weight pattern expressed by those synapses becomes fr=
actured over the course of adaptation.  Thus the encoding itself would not =
need to express an explicitly fractured concept.

ken

uting resources are always a
